channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: State Media Outlets Call Xi Jinping Cartoon a First
item.description: The infographic portrays President Xi Jinping as diligent and hard-working, and how he is kept busy even during public holidays.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: A cartoon image of President Xi Jinping published by Chinese state media.

item.title: 25 Deaths Are Reported in Fierce Clashes in Kiev
item.description: As desperate antigovernment protesters faced riot police officers in the Ukrainian capital, Washington urgently warned American citizens of the increasing danger in the country.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The Ukrainian riot police stood back from burning barricades around Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine, early Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Quick Slide to Curling Success
item.description: A Winter Olympics event that has a mere 15-year history in China is evidence of the country’s ability to devote significant resources to niche sports.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: From left, Xu Xiaoming, Zang Jialiang and Ba Dexin of China competing against Britain at the Winter Olympics on Monday.

item.title: North Korea Arrests Christian Missionary From Australia
item.description: The arrest of John Short comes as North Korea continues to face pressure to release an American missionary it has held for more than a year.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chilling Phone Call Adds to Hurdles of Publishing Xi Jinping Book
item.description: Plans to publish a book depicting China’s president, Xi Jinping, as a thuggish politician have encountered worrisome hurdles in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: The Chinese author Yu Jie at a news conference in Washington in 2012.

item.title: Former Marine in Tehran Jail Retains a Top Iranian Lawyer
item.description: Amir Hekmati, held on spying charges, has retained a lawyer with influential political ties who has lobbied successfully for another foreigner who was detained in Iran.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: DealBook: Lending Where Banks Can’t, Blackstone Thrives in Ireland
item.description: Crippled by bad loans and regulatory restraints, European banks are ceding ground to firms like Blackstone and others that can lend money like a bank but are not scrutinized as such.
item.dc:creator: By LANDON THOMAS JR.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Eircom phone booth in Dublin. Eircom’s default in 2012 was the largest in Irish history.

item.title: Chinese Firm and France to Buy Stakes in Peugeot
item.description: The board of the struggling automaker has approved a plan to raise around 3 billion euros in fresh capital.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH and DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Afghan Ethnic Tensions Rise in Media and Politics
item.description: In Afghanistan, a growing uproar over ethnicity — Pashtun, Tajik, Hazara and Uzbek — has many concerned about possible violence, especially those who remember the country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and HABIB ZAHORI
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Militant Group Says It Attacked Tourist Bus in Sinai
item.description: The assertion by Ansar Beit al-Maqdis signaled an ominous turn in a battle militants have waged against the government since the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Politics to Shadow Obama’s Trade Talks in Mexico
item.description: President Obama will make a brief trip to Mexico to forge closer trade ties with Mexico and Canada, as his party’s leaders in Congress vow to undercut his efforts.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: The Lede: Live Video From Kiev
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people followed the violence in Kiev on Tuesday as it unfolded, reading updates from reporters and activists in Independence Square and watching the local website Espreso.tv’s live YouTube video stream from the besieged protest camp there.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Venezuelan Opposition Chief Surrenders, but Not Without a Rally
item.description: Before giving himself up, Leopoldo López, accused of inciting violence during recent antigovernment protests, addressed the largest rally in over two weeks of growing demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The opposition leader Leopoldo López addressed thousands of supporters in Caracas on Tuesday before giving himself up to the authorities.

item.title: The Lede: Venezuelan Protest Leader Surrenders to Authorities
item.description: Leopoldo López, the political face of ongoing demonstrations against the government, came out of hiding, as he had promised, to face charges of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIE KITROEFF

item.title: Atterwasch Journal: German Village Resists Plans to Strip It Away for the Coal Underneath
item.description: Even as Germany tries to wean itself from fossil fuels and nuclear power, its hunger for coal threatens the existence of villages like Atterwasch that lie atop coal deposits.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal mine in Jänschwalde, Germany. The mining company, Vattenfall, wants to expand into Atterwasch.

item.title: Kiev Protesters Set Square Ablaze to Thwart Police
item.description: Street battles in Kiev between protesters and the riot police underscored the volatility of the political crisis. More than a dozen people were killed, including two security officers, according to the police.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The Ukrainian riot police stood back from burning barricades around Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine, early Wednesday.

item.title: Nuclear Talks With Iran Start Slowly
item.description: Representatives of Iran met with representatives of the United States and other major powers in Vienna to try to chart a path to an agreement.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Representatives of Iran, the United States, China, Russia, Britain, France, Germany and the European Union at talks on Tuesday in Vienna.

item.title: South Sudan’s Forces Clash With Rebels Near U.N. Base
item.description: A battle in an oil-rich part of South Sudan was the most significant violation of the nearly month-old cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: South Sudanese rebel fighters in Upper Nile State, where clashes continue despite a cease-fire.

item.title: Ex-U.S. Lawmaker Charged With Pornography Possession in Zimbabwe
item.description: The arrest is the latest legal entanglement for former Representative Mel Reynolds of Illinois.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:description: Former Representative Mel Reynolds of Illinois was arrested at his hotel in Harare, the capital.

item.title: Coaching Americans and Canadians, but Russian Through and Through
item.description: Marina Zoueva groomed the gold and silver medalists in ice dancing into winners in Sochi.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Marina Zoueva, right, is the coach of the Americans Meryl Davis, left, and Charlie White, who won the first ice-dancing gold medal for the United States. She also coaches the Canadians Tessa Virtue and Scott Moir, who took silver.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Godot Arrives in Sarajevo
item.description: Across Bosnia and Herzegovina, protesters are taking control of their future.
item.dc:creator: By SRECKO HORVAT

item.title: After Delays, Musharraf Appears Before Pakistani Court
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, the former military ruler of Pakistan, finally made an appearance before a special court that is deciding whether to try him for treason.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: European Finance Ministers Revisit Plans for Failing Banks
item.description: The leaders looked at new ways to appease critics who said their proposal would be too cumbersome and take too long to introduce.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Listening Post: Aide’s Return to White House Reflects Changing U.S. Role in Middle East
item.description: Robert Malley, who advised President Bill Clinton on Israeli-Palestinian talks, is returning to manage the fraying ties between the United States and its allies in the Persian Gulf.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: El País Ousts Editor; 3rd Spanish Paper to Do So Amid Financial Woes
item.description: The departure of Javier Moreno at Spain’s leading daily newspaper is a new sign of economic turmoil caused by slumping advertising and dwindling circulation.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER and DOREEN CARVAJAL
